ISFL: Federated Learning for Non-i.i.d. Data with Local Importance Sampling ††thanks: Zheqi Zhu, and Pingyi Fan are with Beijing National Research Center for Information Science and Technology and the Department of Electronic Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing 10084, China (e-mail: zhuzq18@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn, fpy@tsinghua.edu.cn). Chenghui Peng is with the Wireless Technology Laboratory, Huawei Technologies, Shenzhen 518129, China (e-mail: pengchenghui@huawei.com). Khaled B. Letaief is with the Department of ECE, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong (email: eekhaled@ust.hk). * Pingyi Fan is the corresponding author. For preprint.

Zheqi Zhu, Pingyi Fan, , Chenghui Peng, and Khaled B. Letaief
Abstract

As a promising learning paradigm integrating computation and communication, federated learning (FL) proceeds the local training and the periodic sharing from distributed clients. Due to the non-i.i.d. data distribution on clients, FL model suffers from the gradient diversity, poor performance, bad convergence, etc. In this work, we aim to tackle this key issue by adopting importance sampling (IS) for local training. We propose importance sampling federated learning (ISFL), an explicit framework with theoretical guarantees. Firstly, we derive the convergence theorem of ISFL to involve the effects of local importance sampling. Then, we formulate the problem of selecting optimal IS weights and obtain the theoretical solutions. We also employ a water-filling method to calculate the IS weights and develop the ISFL algorithms. The experimental results on CIFAR-10 fit the proposed theorems well and verify that ISFL reaps better performance, sampling efficiency, as well as explainability on non-i.i.d. data. To the best of our knowledge, ISFL is the first non-i.i.d. FL solution from the local sampling aspect which exhibits theoretical compatibility with neural network models. Furthermore, as a local sampling approach, ISFL can be easily migrated into other emerging FL frameworks.

Index Terms:
federated learning, importance sampling, non i.i.d data, water-filling optimization.

I Introduction

I-A Backgrounds

As a novel paradigm for distributed intelligent system, federated learning (FL) has received great attention in both research and application areas [1]. The core idea of FL is to share the models of distributed clients, which train models using their local data. Basic federated learning systems consist of two stages: 1) Local training, where clients update their local models with local data; and 2) Central aggregation, where the parameter server aggregates the models uploaded from the clients and sends the global models back. Different from the traditional distributed learning methods that split the models or transmit the data, model parameters or gradients are designed to be the elements for client interaction in FL schemes. FL is recognized as a communication-efficient scheme for its full use of the client-center (client-client) communication, clients’ computation capability, and the distributed data sources[2, 3].

The structures of FL naturally fit the distributed intelligent systems where computing is coupled with communication [4]. On the one hand, FL can serve the hierarchical computing-communication systems such as edge computing or fog computing, where a cloud center and distributed devices/clusters participate. A number of applications emerge especially in the mobile scenarios such as artificial intelligence of Things (AIoT) and vehicular internet [5, 6]. The potentials of FL have been investigated in distributed inference [7], system optimization [8] and cooperative control [9]. In particular, due to the efficient sharing mechanism of FL, its combinations with reinforcement learning (RL) or multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) have been considered, which is referred to as federated RL (FRL) [10]. The corresponding frameworks have been designed for collaboration and scheduling of intelligent edge computing systems in [11, 12]. On the other hand, distributed computing systems can also serve federated learning tasks. With the development of wireless communication, intelligent devices and the lightweight machine learning models, FL is envisioned as one of the core technologies in 6G systems [13, 14]. These mobile systems support the FL to be deployed in numerous emerging applications, such as VR/AR, smart city, etc. [15].

Recently, FL has been evolving from many aspects and some learning schemes of traditional deep learning areas have also been migrated into FL. Furthermore, some theoretical studies on FL arise. For instance, Stich [16] derived the convergence of the local SGD for the first time, and Wang et al.[17] bounded the gradient norms under several FL settings. Considering the communication factors, the joint analysis and the guide for system design are further studied in [18, 19]. These theoretical analysis guarantees the interpretability, robustness, generalization, privacy protection of FL and makes such learning schemes trustworthy [20].

I-B Motivations

Distributed learning systems suffer from the heterogeneity of both the clients and data. Particularly, as mentioned in [21], the heterogeneity of distributed data, also referred to as non-i.i.d. (independent and identically distributed) data settings, is one of the most crucial issues in FL. In this work, we consider a commonly acknowledged perspective of FL non-i.i.d. setting, the data category distribution skew, which is typically represented in real world datasets. For example, the label distributions of clients’ training data make a difference on the global performance in classification tasks [22]. Such non-i.i.d. data impacts FL from two aspects: Firstly, the data distributions highly differ for different clients, resulting in the divergence of local models; The second one is the imbalanced local data, which leads to bad generalization and the overfitting of the local models. Therefore, FL on non-i.i.d. data faces major challenges including slow convergence and unsatisfactory performance [23].

In conventional centralized deep learning, importance sampling (IS) is regarded as an effective method to mitigate the data imbalance [24]. Both theoretical and experimental analysis has verified its improvement on accuracy [25], as well as training speed [26]. In addition to investigating the importance sampling theoretically, these studies also provided new comprehensions of the optimal IS weights. For instance, iterative parameter estimation methods such as Monte Carlo based approaches can be adopted to estimate the weights [27]. By figuring out the factors that determines the optimal sampling, the sampling parameters can be further combined with the RL to automatically learn the adaptive sampling strategies [28].

I-C Related Works

In the literature, some related work on non-i.i.d. FL has been studied from different aspects. The popular solutions include data sharing, augmentation, model distillation, client selection, clustering, and sampling based methods. Here we mainly list the studies tightly related to ours.

As for FL with sampling approach to tackle non-i.i.d. data, Tudor et al.[29] proposed a method to identify the data relevance at each client, based on which the data are sampled for local training before the learning tasks start. To extend the dynamic sampling strategies, Li et al.[30] measured each sample’s importance by its gradient norms during the training and designed the FL algorithms with client+sample selection. Such data-driven method requires calculating the instant gradient norm of each training sample, which means that the extra backward propagation shall be processed locally. Another systematic work on importance sampling FL was done in [31], where both data and client sampling are considered. The importance weights of the mini-batches were derived theoretically and the convergence of algorithms was also analyzed. However, the theoretical guarantees were carried based on the convex-function assumption which is not compatible with deep learning models such as neural networks. Besides, the experiments were tested on a simple regression problem [32]. Thus, the theoretical analysis of importance sampling based FL in deep learning tasks is still an open problem.

There are other important theoretical results on non-i.i.d. FL. Li et al.[33] established the connections between convergence rate and the factors including federated period, gradient Lipschitz, gradient norms, etc. Zhao et al.[34] derived the upper bounds of the parameter deviations between FL on non-i.i.d. data and the centralized training on full data. They also pointed out that the gradient Lipschitz of different categories shall be introduced to describe the non-i.i.d. impacts on the performance gaps. These previous works inspired us to start this work.

I-D Contributions & Paper Organization

The main contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows:

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We put forward a generalized Importance Sampling Federated Learning framework, abbreviated as ISFL11footnotemark: 1, which introduces the local importance sampling to mitigate the impacts of the non-i.i.d. data distribution.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We derive the convergence theorem for ISFL, which relaxes the convexity assumptions for better compatibility with deep learning models. The theoretical result generalizes the FL convergence analysis by introducing the effects of local importance sampling.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We formulate the weight selection of each client as independent sub-problems. The theoretical solutions for the optimal sampling strategies, as well as an adaptive water-filling approach for calculating the optimum IS weights are also presented.

  • ∙∙\bullet

    We develop the corresponding ISFL algorithms111The codes in this work are available at https://github.com/Zhuzzq/ISFL and carry several experiments based on the CIFAR-10 dataset. It will be shown that the outcomes fit the theorems well and verify the improvement of the proposed algorithms. The experiments also suggest that ISFL is able to approach the accuracy of centralized training. Some insights on the generalization ability, personalized preference, interpretability, as well as data efficiency are also discussed.

The rest of the article is organized as follows. In Section II, we introduce some necessary preliminaries and the basic idea of ISFL. In Section III, we derive the theoretical results on the framework analysis and the optimal weighting calculation. The corresponding ISFL algorithms are developed in Section IV. Experiment evaluations and further discussions are presented in Section V. Finally, in Section VI, we conclude this work and point out several potential research directions.

II Preliminaries and ISFL Framework

In this section, we present important preliminaries and introduce local importance sampling into FL. We will then sketch the basic idea and the framework of ISFL. Some key notations are listed in Table I.

II-A Federated Learning for Non-i.i.d. Data

By sharing the trained model parameters, FL serves as a communication-efficient paradigm for distributed learning. The goal of FL is to obtain a global model which performs optimal global loss, i.e.,

ℓ​(𝜽¯t):=𝔼ξ∼𝒑ℓ​(ξ;𝜽¯t)=∑i=1Cpi​ℓ​(ξi;𝜽¯t).assignℓsubscript¯𝜽𝑡subscript𝔼similar-to𝜉𝒑ℓ𝜉subscript¯𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscript𝑝𝑖ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖subscript¯𝜽𝑡\ell(\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}):=\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle\xi\sim\boldsymbol{p}}\ell\big{(}\xi;\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}\big{)}=\sum_{i=1}^{C}p_{i}\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}\big{)}. (1)

The classical FL proceeds by merging the distributed models periodically to obtain the global model:

𝜽¯t=∑k=1Kπk​𝜽tkif​t≡0modElformulae-sequencesubscript¯𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜋𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡if𝑡modulo0subscript𝐸𝑙\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}_{t}\qquad{\rm if}\ t\equiv 0\mod{E_{l}} (2)

where πksubscript𝜋𝑘\pi_{k} is the weight222Such weights are mainly considered in client selection. In the context of this work, we focus the weights of local training data. for client k𝑘k, and 𝜽tksuperscriptsubscript𝜽𝑡𝑘\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}^{k} is the local model of client k. For FedAvg [1], πk=|𝒟k|∑l=1K|𝒟l|subscript𝜋𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑙1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑙\pi_{k}=\frac{|\mathcal{D}_{k}|}{\sum_{l=1}^{K}|\mathcal{D}_{l}|}. All clients download the updated global model 𝜽¯tsubscript¯𝜽𝑡\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t} every Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} epochs. Since FL conducts a parameter-level fusion, the local training significantly affects the global performance. Each client tends to update the model towards the local optimum which fits its own training data. Thus, one of the most crucial challenges for FL is the non-i.i.d. data distribution, which usually causes the local gradients and model parameters to diverge as shown in Fig. 1. Compared to centralized training on whole data, the deviation of the distributed clients hinders the global model from reaching the optimum solution using the whole data, which also leads to poor performance, as well as bad convergence.

II-B Importance Sampling

Importance Sampling (IS) provides an intuitive solution to make up the gap between the observed distribution (can be obtained from observation) and the target distribution (inherent and latent) [35]. Consider a certain function f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) of a random variable x𝑥x, and let q​(x)𝑞𝑥q(x) be the latent target distribution and p​(x)𝑝𝑥p(x) be the observed one. Through sampling the data according to IS weights w​(x)𝑤𝑥w(x) satisfying ∫w​(x)​p​(x)​𝑑x=1𝑤𝑥𝑝𝑥differential-d𝑥1\int w(x)p(x)dx=1, the re-sampled observation can be expressed as:

𝔼x∼𝒑[w​(x)​f​(x)]:=∫p​(x)​w​(x)​f​(x)​𝑑x.assignsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝒑delimited-[]𝑤𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑝𝑥𝑤𝑥𝑓𝑥differential-d𝑥\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle x\sim\boldsymbol{p}}\left[w(x)f(x)\right]:=\int p(x)w(x)f(x)dx. (3)

IS attempts to find proper weights which make the re-sampled observation close to the target expectation, i.e.,

𝔼x∼𝒒[f​(x)]:=∫q​(x)​f​(x)​𝑑x.assignsubscript𝔼similar-to𝑥𝒒delimited-[]𝑓𝑥𝑞𝑥𝑓𝑥differential-d𝑥\mathop{\mathbb{E}}\limits_{\scriptscriptstyle x\sim\boldsymbol{q}}\left[f(x)\right]:=\int q(x)f(x)dx. (4)

Particularly, if w​(x)𝑤𝑥w(x) are set ideally as q​(x)p​(x)𝑞𝑥𝑝𝑥\frac{q(x)}{p(x)}, then the observed expectation with IS is equivalent to the objective. In general, iterative algorithms are adopted to estimate the optimal IS weights, as summarized in [36]. Numerous varieties of IS algorithms have been developed and their applications in machine learning area have also been exploited. This inspires us to combine IS with local training to relieve the dilemma caused by non-i.i.d. data.

II-C ISFL Framework

As mentioned, the non-i.i.d. settings and the imbalanced distribution of the local data lead to the model divergence. We shall assume that there exists certain data sampling strategies from which all clients collaborate to make the global model reach a better performance. Hence, we introduce importance sampling for local training on each client and formulate FL with importance sampling, abbreviated as ISFL. In traditional FL, the clients sample their local training data uniformly to carry out the backward-propagation (BP) with the mini-batch SGD based optimizer. Thus, the sampling probabilities are 𝒑k={pik}superscript𝒑𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑖\boldsymbol{p}^{k}=\{p^{k}_{i}\} and the local SGD of a batch in a single iteration on client k𝑘k can be expressed as:

𝜽t+1k←𝜽tk−η​∑i=1Cpik​∇ℓ​(ξi;𝜽tk).←subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑖∇ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{k}_{t+1}\leftarrow{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{k}_{t}-\eta\sum_{i=1}^{C}p^{k}_{i}\nabla\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{k}_{t}\big{)}. (5)

In ISFL, clients resample their local training data according to a set of IS weights {wik≥0}subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘𝑖0\{w^{k}_{i}\geq 0\}, which satisfies ∑i=1Cpik​wik=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘𝑖1\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}p_{i}^{k}w^{k}_{i}=1 for k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K. Then, the local SGD in ISFL shall be changed into:

𝜽t+1k←𝜽tk−η​∑i=1Cpik​wik​∇ℓ​(ξi;𝜽tk).←subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡1subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡𝜂superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘𝑖∇ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{k}_{t+1}\leftarrow{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{k}_{t}-\eta\sum_{i=1}^{C}p^{k}_{i}w^{k}_{i}\nabla\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{k}_{t}\big{)}. (6)

For simplicity, we use qik=pik​wiksubscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘𝑖q^{k}_{i}=p_{i}^{k}w^{k}_{i} to represent the re-sampling probabilities in ISFL. Furthermore, the non-i.i.d dilemma cannot be tackled by simply resampling with the probability 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} because the model aggregation interacts with the local training. Both procedures are coupled, which together affect the performance of FL. Therefore, the optimal local sampling strategies {𝒒k⁣∗}superscript𝒒𝑘\{\boldsymbol{q}^{k*}\} for each client are unintuitive and dynamic. The design principle of {𝒒k}superscript𝒒𝑘\{\boldsymbol{q}^{k}\} shall be well formulated.

The basic workflow of ISFL is shown in Fig. 2. Clients proceed their local training with the data sampled under the IS weights. The theorems in the next section will demonstrate that the optimal IS weights are related to not only the above two distributions, but also the model parameters. Since the local models change as the training goes on, the IS weights shall be updated iteratively. Thus, ISFL conducts IS weight updating synchronously with the model sharing at every federated round.

III Theoretical Results

In this section, we will firstly generalize the FL convergence analysis by introducing local IS to FL. Secondly, based on the convergence theorem, the optimal IS weights are obtained theoretically.

III-A Convergence Analysis with Local Importance Sampling

Similar to most of the convergence theorems, we first state the following assumptions which are commonly exploited to support the theoretical analysis. Particularly, to improve the theoretical compatibility with neural networks, we relax the assumption of the loss functions’ convexity or μ𝜇\mu-strong convexity, which are widely used in some studies.

Assumption 1 (Conditional L-smoothness [17, 34]).

During a given continuous training period 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} and for training samples ξisubscript𝜉𝑖\xi_{i} of category i𝑖i, the gradient of the model is Lipschitz continuous, i.e., the loss function satisfies:

‖∇ℓ​(ξi;𝜽)−∇ℓ​(ξi;𝜽′)‖≤Li​(𝒯)​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,norm∇ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖𝜽∇ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖superscript𝜽′subscript𝐿𝑖𝒯norm𝜽superscript𝜽′\left\|\nabla\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};\boldsymbol{\theta}\big{)}-\nabla\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\big{)}\right\|\leq L_{i}(\mathcal{T})\left\|\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\right\|, (7)

where Li​(𝒯)subscript𝐿𝑖𝒯L_{i}(\mathcal{T}) is termed as the (empirical) gradient Lipschitz.

Note that there does not exist the invariant gradient Lipschitz constant for deep learning models such as neural networks. Thus, the assumption allows the gradient Lipschitz to vary as the federated updating proceeds. Furthermore, for given dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}, the empirical gradient Lipschitz between local model 𝜽tksubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}_{t} and global model 𝜽¯tsubscript¯𝜽𝑡\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t} at every global epoch can be defined as:

Lk,i​(t):=maxξi∈𝒟⁡‖∇ℓ​(ξi;𝜽tk)−∇ℓ​(ξi;𝜽¯t)‖‖𝜽tk−𝜽¯t‖,assignsubscript𝐿𝑘𝑖𝑡subscriptsubscript𝜉𝑖𝒟norm∇ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡∇ℓsubscript𝜉𝑖subscript¯𝜽𝑡normsubscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡subscript¯𝜽𝑡L_{k,i}(t):=\max_{\xi_{i}\in\mathcal{D}}\ \frac{\Big{\|}\nabla\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}_{t}\big{)}-\nabla\ell\big{(}\xi_{i};\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}\big{)}\Big{\|}}{\big{\|}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}_{t}-\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}\big{\|}}, (8)

when t=m​El𝑡𝑚subscript𝐸𝑙t=mE_{l}.

Assumption 2 (Bounded SGD variance [16, 17]).

The stochastic gradient variance of each model 𝛉tksubscriptsuperscript𝛉𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}_{t} at epoch t𝑡t is bounded by:

The full proof of Theorem 1 is presented in Appendix A.

Remark 1 (Interpretation of the bound).

Theorem 1 extends the FL convergence results by considering the effects of local importance sampling. Similar to some existing studies such as [17] and [37], the divergence of gradient norm comes from 3 parts: 1) The first term in RHS of (1) is the related to the remaining gap with the optimum loss function after previous T0subscript𝑇0T_{0} round federated learning; 2) The second term ψ​(t)𝜓𝑡\psi(t) is the gradient deviation caused by the subsequent model aggregation; 3) The third term mainly comes from the local training with IS and model aggregation during the subsequent progress. Particularly, the modified multiplier ρ𝒯​(𝐪k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝐪𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) illustrates the influence of the local IS under {𝐪k}superscript𝐪𝑘\{\boldsymbol{q}^{k}\}.

Theorem 1 generalizes the original convergence analysis of FL by considering the impacts of local importance sampling. The result is also intuitive since the local importance sampling shows its effect for subsequent local training and model aggregation by multiplying the factor ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) on the original deviations. Notably, the third term of the upper bound in (1) is related to clients’ local sampling probabilities {𝒒k}superscript𝒒𝑘\{\boldsymbol{q}^{k}\}. Thus, we shall mainly focus on this term in the next to investigate the theoretically optimal sampling strategies.

III-B Optimal Importance Sampling Strategies

The aforementioned theorem implies how local IS probabilities affect the ISFL convergence rate. Based on Theorem 1, we can formulate the optimization problem to minimize the upper bound for better model performance. Note that with the client weights {πk}subscript𝜋𝑘\{\pi_{k}\} fixed, only the third term in (1) is related to the local IS probabilities {𝒒k}superscript𝒒𝑘\{\boldsymbol{q}^{k}\}. Therefore, the solutions to optimal local sampling strategies shall be handled independently on each client. In other words, the general optimization problem of IS can be decomposed into K𝐾K sub-problems minimizing ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}). Besides, to ensure that samples of each category are sampled at least with a low probability, we set the lowest IS weight ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi and guarantee the condition qik≥ϖ​piksuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑘italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘q_{i}^{k}\geq\varpi p_{i}^{k}. Then, we are able to formulate the decomposed optimization problems for the T𝑇T-step period 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} as follows.

𝒫𝒯k::subscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯absent\displaystyle\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}}:\quad min𝒒ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝒒subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\displaystyle\min\limits_{\boldsymbol{q}}\quad\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) (14)
s.t.{∑i=1Cqik=1qik≥ϖ⋅piki=1,⋯,C\displaystyle s.t.\quad\begin{cases}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}q_{i}^{k}=1&\\ q_{i}^{k}\geq\varpi\cdot p_{i}^{k}&\quad i=1,\cdots,C\end{cases} (14a)

For each client k𝑘k, its optimal local IS probabilities during 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} can be obtained by solving 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}}. The following theorem gives the theoretical solutions of the optimal IS strategies.

Theorem 2 (Optimal IS Probabilities).

For given period 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}, the optimal probabilities of local importance sampling for client k𝑘k are:

qjk⁣∗=max⁡{ϖ​pjk,pj+αjk​(𝒯)⋅Γk​(λ)},superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗⋅subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯subscriptΓ𝑘𝜆q_{j}^{k*}=\max\Bigl{\{}\varpi p_{j}^{k},p_{j}+\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})\cdot\Gamma_{k}(\lambda)\Bigr{\}}, (15)

where

is a zero-sum factor representing the gap between the empirical gradient Lipschitz of category j𝑗j and the average value. Γk​(λ)=C​λ∑iLk,i2​(𝒯)−1subscriptΓ𝑘𝜆𝐶𝜆subscript𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑖𝒯1\Gamma_{k}(\lambda)=\sqrt{\frac{C\lambda}{\sum_{i}L^{2}_{k,i}(\mathcal{T})}-1} is a factor related to the Lagrangian multiplier λ𝜆\lambda.

See the proof in Appendix B-A.

Theorem 2 indicates that the optimal IS probabilities are determined by the global category distribution plus a zero-sum factor related to the gradient Lipschitz. In general, ISFL up-samples the category with a large global proportion or a small gradient Lipschitz. The principle of the optimal local IS strategies can be explained as follows. Two kinds of data categories shall be used more frequently: 1) The categories with larger proportion possess more data samples, which helps the model learn more patterns and improves the local performance; 2) On the other hand, categories with small gradient Lipschitz will benefit the global model convergence at federated epochs. Therefore, in FL for non-i.i.d. data, instead of intuitively resampling the data according to the global distribution (up-sample the smaller proportion and down-sample the higher), we should also consider the offset term in (31), which reflects the impacts of the gradient deviation and aggregation. Overall, the solutions to the sub-problems 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} is to resample the local training data with the IS weights {qik⁣∗/pik}superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑖\{q_{i}^{k*}/p^{k}_{i}\}. Moreover, the exact values of the optimal IS weights can be solved by a water-filling approach as shown in Remark 2.

Remark 2.

Let qjk​(Γ)=pj+αjk​(𝒯)⋅Γk​(λ)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘Γsubscript𝑝𝑗⋅subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯subscriptΓ𝑘𝜆q_{j}^{k}(\Gamma)=p_{j}+\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})\cdot\Gamma_{k}(\lambda). Note that the k𝑘k-th client’s optimal IS probability for category j𝑗j is the maximum between ϖ​pjkitalic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘\varpi p_{j}^{k} and qjk​(Γ)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘Γq_{j}^{k}(\Gamma). Besides, Γk​(λ)subscriptΓ𝑘𝜆\Gamma_{k}(\lambda) is a monotonic function of λ𝜆\lambda and Γ​(λ)≥0Γ𝜆0\Gamma(\lambda)\geq 0 always holds. Thus, we only need to consider the optimal non-negative Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*}. Then, the numerical solutions in (15) can be calculated by choosing a proper Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} through a classical water-filling approach as shown in Fig. 3.

By adopting a water-filling approach, we only need to find a proper Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} to guarantee that the lowest sampling probability ϖ​pjkitalic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘\varpi p_{j}^{k} falls below qjk​(Γ)superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘Γq_{j}^{k}(\Gamma), which is the water-filling level height of Category j𝑗j. Furthermore, we formulate the following Theorem 3 to show how the optimal factor Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} is calculated through the water-filling method.

Theorem 3 (Calculation of Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*}).

For client k𝑘k, if the lowest IS weight ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi is properly set to satisfy pj≥ϖ​pjksubscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑗p_{j}\geq\varpi p^{k}_{j} for all categories j=1,⋯,C𝑗1⋯𝐶j=1,\cdots,C, through the water-filling approach, the optimal factor Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} in (15) shall be chosen as

Γ∗=minj⁡{pj−ϖ​pjk−αjk​(𝒯)|pj−ϖ​pjk−αjk​(𝒯)≥0},superscriptΓsubscript𝑗conditionalsubscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯subscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯0\Gamma^{*}=\min_{j}\left\{\frac{p_{j}-\varpi p_{j}^{k}}{-\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})}\bigg{|}\frac{p_{j}-\varpi p_{j}^{k}}{-\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})}\geq 0\right\}, (17)

if the set is not empty.

The proof is given in Appendix B-B.

Overall, according to Theorem 2 and Theorem 3, we theoretically solve 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} and obtain the optimal local IS strategies for each client.

IV Algorithm Designs

In this section, based on above theoretical results, we formulate the formal ISFL algorithms. Some practical issues and the costs will also be discussed.

IV-A ISFL Algorithms

ISFL generalizes the original FL training process at the federated epoch. In addition to collecting, aggregating and sending back the updated model parameters to clients, the center also calculates and hands out the optimal IS weights for each client. According to Theorem 3, we first develop the water-filling algorithm to calculate the optimal IS strategies as Algorithm 1.

In practice, since the local empirical gradient Lipschitz change with the model aggregation since the local models are replaced as new global model every Elsubscript𝐸𝑙E_{l} epochs. Therefore, {Lk,i}subscript𝐿𝑘𝑖\{L_{k,i}\} and the IS weights shall be updated synchronously with the model aggregation at every federated epoch. When clients finish a set of local training, the gradient Lipschitz will be updated. Meanwhile, the IS weights for next local training epochs will be renewed. The full procedures of FL with local IS, ISFL, will be referred to as Algorithm 2.

Specifically, Lines 3 to 6 in Algorithm 2 is the local training with importance sampling on each client. Lines 8, 9 and 13 comprise the traditional federated parameter updating. The IS weight updating is carried out in Lines 11 and 12. ISFL can be regarded as a modified version of the original FL algorithms with additional operations at the local training and federated updating:

  • 1)

    During local epochs, ISFL introduces the dynamic importance sampling of training data for local training, which re-weights the samples of different categories to combat the impact of non-i.i.d. data.

  • 2)

    At federated rounds, besides the traditional parameter upload/download, ISFL adds extra operations: updating the gradient Lipschitz, calculating the renewed IS weights, and sending them back to clients simultaneously through the parameter downlinks.

IV-B Practical Issues

As discussed above, the local empirical gradient Lipschitz change with the model aggregation and the optimal IS weights shall be updated every federated epoch. In this work, we update the empirical gradient Lipschitz using a small and non-sensitive dataset 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} according to (8) to protect the privacy of clients in FL.

The deployment of ISFL is flexible. The IS weight updating can be proceeded either centrally at parameter server or locally on each client. Note that the procedures consist of gradient Lipschitz updating and the IS weight calculation, where the former requires excessive computation. Therefore, we prefer to deploy the empirical gradient updating at the parameter server for better system efficiency. With the local data distribution uploaded, the optimal IS weights can be calculated at the server and sent back to each client. Particularly, if the local data distributions are considered to be the clients’ privacy, the IS weights shall be updated locally with the necessary factors transmitted instead.

As for the cost of introducing ISFL into original FL, the extra communication costs can be neglected because at each federated rounds, clients only need to download the IS weights or the factors for local calculation, which take up far less capacity compared to the transmission of the model parameters. However, considerable computation costs are inevitable. The main computation consumption occurs while updating the empirical gradient Lipschitz, where the per-sample backward propagation shall be executed for each client using the selected dataset 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L}. Thus, the additional cost is 2×K×|𝒟L|2𝐾subscript𝒟𝐿2\times K\times|\mathcal{D}_{L}| times gradient computation at every round of model aggregation. Note that such excessive computation is only decided by the size of 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} and will not increase as the local data grows.

As a result, the gradient Lipschitz updating at the federated round causes additional computation at the parameter server or distributed clients. Since this work focuses on investigating the ISFL framework, the corresponding computation scheduling and the alternative estimation of the gradient Lipschitz will not be considered in this paper. Both of them are indeed the important topics and also interesting, we may discuss it in the future.

V Experimental Evaluation

In this section, to evaluate our proposals, we carry out experiments on a popular image classification task, CIFAR-10. The corresponding FL algorithms are implemented with PyTorch. The details of the experiment configurations, the results and the insights will be presented below.

V-A Experiment Setups

In the basic experiments, we consider an FL system with 20 clients which fully participate the aggregation. The detailed settings and learning configurations are listed in Table II. We set the maximum global epoch as 25, respectively. During each global epoch, clients train their models locally for 5 epochs. The local data of each client are divided into batches with size of 128 to carry the mini-batch SGD training. Besides, we update the gradient Lipschitz using a small dataset 𝒟Lsubscript𝒟𝐿\mathcal{D}_{L} by (8) with 500 samples randomly selected from the unused dataset.

V-A1 Dataset and Model

Our experiments are carried based on a popular image classification dataset, CIFAR-10. Since the goal is to verify the effectiveness of the proposed ISFL schemes, we are not aiming at the state-of-the-art performance. As for the neural network model, we adopt a light-weight ResNet [38] with 2 residual convolutional blocks and 8 trainable layers in total (ResNet8). The centralized model trained on full dataset reaches 91.25% accuracy.

V-A2 Non-i.i.d. Settings

We implement commonly used label-level non-i.i.d. settings similar to [34]. It carries sort-and-partition data split: (a) All the data samples are sorted by their labels and then divided equally into shards. Each shard has 500 images with (1−N​R)1𝑁𝑅(1-N\!R) proportion uniformly sampled from all categories; and (b) Each client randomly takes 2 shards. Overall, each client possesses 1000 training samples. The whole data of all clients is referred to as global data, 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G}. Since the global data i.e., the ensemble of the clients’ data might still be imbalanced, we test the model performance not only on the standard CIFAR-10 test dataset 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S}, but also on the global data 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G}. The test on 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G} reflects the convergence and training efficiency of FL algorithms. The test on 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} implies the generalization ability of the model because the data distribution differs from the integrated data for the non-i.i.d. settings. We set two cases with N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.95 and 0.98, respectively, to represent different degrees of non-i.i.d. data.

V-A3 Baselines and Comparisons

In the following experiments, we choose FedAvg as the baseline and implement the importance sampling methods based on it. For comparisons, we select two IS based methods, GradNorm-IS and RW-IS. GradNorm-IS samples local data according to its gradient norms, i.e., more weight is given to a data sample that has a greater gradient norm as proposed in [32]. Thus, GradNorm-IS carries out a per-sample IS weight calculation, which requires more |𝒟G|subscript𝒟𝐺|\mathcal{D}_{G}| times gradient computation locally on clients for each weight updating. RW-IS is an intuitive sampling strategy which re-weights the data and forces to sample the local training data uniformly. As RW-IS fixes the sampling weights according to local distribution, no excessive computation is required.

V-B Accuracy and Convergence

We test two different non-i.i.d. data split settings with N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.95 and N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.98. The local data distributions are shown in Fig. 4(a) and 4(d). To evaluate the performance of several training settings and methods, we compare ISFL with the original FL algorithm FedAvg and two sampling based schemes. The accuracy comparisons of different learning schemes on 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G} are presented in Fig. 4(b) and 4(e) and the numerical results are listed in Table III. One can observe that for the non-i.i.d. data, both FedAvg and GradNorm-IS perform poorly in terms of accuracy, convergence, and stability. It is worthy to be noted that though gradient-norm based importance sampling was proved to improve the non-i.i.d. FL for regression models [32], such scheme seems not well compatible with the neural network models which do not satisfy the convexity assumption of loss functions. Specifically, assigning higher weights to the data sample with larger gradient norm cannot effectively reduce the divergence of local SGD while employing the NN models. Such phenomena will be explained in detail through the sampling weight discussions later. In contrast, RW-IS efficiently improves the accuracy under two N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R data settings and performs well on stability. Furthermore, ISFL enhances about 10% / 30% accuracy respectively under two non-i.i.d. data splits. Most notably, as listed in Table III, ISFL nearly reaches the centralized model (trained on the integration of the distributed data) with about 7% and 10% lower accuracy on standard CIFAR-10 test data. We deem that ISFL also narrows the performance gap between FL and centralized learning.

The curves and the numerical results suggest that even under severely non-i.i.d. data (N​R𝑁𝑅N\!R=0.98), ISFL mitigates the performance decays on accuracy, stability and convergence, which strengthens FL’s robustness against imbalance data distribution. The above results indicate that ISFL guarantees the generalization ability of the global model even though the local models are trained on non-i.i.d. data. This also implies ISFL’s potentials for personalized preference. By substituting the {pj}subscript𝑝𝑗\{p_{j}\} in (15) as the distribution that local client prefers, the global model tends to perform well on both standard testing data and the personalized local data.

Besides, ISFL converges most rapidly and reaches the lowest train loss as shown in Fig. 4(c) and 4(f). This also verifies that the convergence bound in Theorem 1 makes sense and the corresponding optimal IS weights effectively improve the convergence of FL with non-i.i.d. data.

As for the setting of the lowest IS weight ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi, we test the ISFL schemes under ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi=0.05 and ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi=0.01. The results in Table III imply that different ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi lead to similar model performance. Such outcome is comprehensible since we set ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi as a small constant in the constraints (14a) of 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} to ensure that all categories could contribute to the federated model at least in a low proportion. Moreover, according to the water-filling solution in Theorem 3, the optimal IS probability is only related to the minimal of ΓΓ\Gamma. Thus, the small value of ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi influence little on ISFL performance.

V-C Evaluation of The Propositions

Then we implement further experiments to evaluate the theoretical results and explain the local sampling strategies of ISFL.

To validate the core theorems of ISFL, we investigate the evolution of the multiplier ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) in Theorem 1, which involves the effects of carrying out local importance sampling. The theoretical minimum of ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) and the real ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) solved by Theorem 2-3 are plotted in Fig. 5, respectively. Both theoretical minimum ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) and experimental ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) decrease with the global epoch. This verifies the reasonability of Theorem 1: Local importance sampling with optimal weights {wjk}subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑘𝑗\{w^{k}_{j}\} reduces the multiplier ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) in (1). In this way, the upper bound of the gradient norm is minimized, and the convergence is strengthened. Moreover, it is easy to confirm that the theoretical optimum and the experimental values of ISFL show same tendency. Two curves get closer and converge stably to a small value as the progress carries on. This indicates that the theoretical optimum ρ𝒯​(𝒒k⁣∗)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k*}) and the proposed solutions are consistent. Thus, we deem that the problem 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} is well solved by Theorem 2 and Theorem 3.

Next, we conduct client-level analysis of importance sampling weights. With the random seeds fixed, Fig. 6 presents the evolution of the local sampling probability {qik}subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑖\{q^{k}_{i}\} under GradNorm-IS and ISFL on selected clients. Fig. 6(a) clearly reveals why gradient norm based IS schemes fail for NN models. Though the categories with large gradient norms take over the most sampling proportion, the gradients of the updated model still remains. In other words, utilizing a data sample frequently in local training does not guarantee that its gradient on the updated model will reduce in future BP steps. Therefore, we tend to explain that sampling methods based on GradNorm might not be well compatible with the FL systems using deep learning models such as NNs. On the contrary, as shown in Fig. 6(b), ISFL seems to carry out a proper sampling strategy. By Algorithm 2, ISFL updates the local IS weights synchronously with the communication rounds. Each client adopts its latest IS weights for the local training epochs. One can observe that the IS probabilities of different categories change dynamically. As shown, ISFL does not simply carry the re-weighting (RW-IS) to sample the data of each category uniformly. Some categories are always sampled with a large probability, while some are occasionally re-weighted to nearly 0 probability. Moreover, the experiments illustrate that some categories with large proportion will be down-sampled but still get a large IS probability than uniform sampling, e.g., Category 1 for Client 7. Meanwhile, some categories with small proportion will be highly up-sample such as Category 3 for Client 10. The experimental results meet the conclusion in Theorems 2 and 3: According to (15), the categories with larger global proportion or smaller empirical gradient Lipschitz might be utilized more frequently in local training.

V-D Sampling Efficiency

Since ISFL is a sampling-based approach, we also evaluate its data efficiency. Different from training the full data in every local epoch, we consider the partial sampling with a sampling ratio S​R𝑆𝑅S\!R, i.e., each client selects only ⌊S​R⋅|𝒟k|⌋⋅𝑆𝑅subscript𝒟𝑘\lfloor S\!R\cdot|\mathcal{D}_{k}|\rfloor samples for training at every local epoch. The comparison results with RW-IS and random sampling are shown in Fig. 7. ISFL not only gets a higher accuracy, but also its performance is stable and robust. The accuracy decay is little with the S​R𝑆𝑅S\!R decreases. Particularly, even though each client only samples 0.1 ratio training data in local epochs, ISFL still preserves 58%, 71% accuracy on 𝒟Ssubscript𝒟𝑆\mathcal{D}_{S} and 𝒟Gsubscript𝒟𝐺\mathcal{D}_{G}, respectively. Thus, ISFL exhibits a better sampling efficiency and data robustness, which is important for the scenarios where the local computation resources/timeliness are restricted.

Overall, the evaluations demonstrate that ISFL improves the original FL on model accuracy, stability, convergence, sampling efficiency, as well as the compatibility with NN models. The experimental results also meet the theoretical deductions based on which the optimal IS weights are derived. The core idea of ISFL strategies can be interpreted as: 1) to up-sample the categories with larger global proportion or 2) to down-sample the categories with larger empirical gradient Lipschitz. For above reasons, we consider ISFL as an effective FL scheme with theoretical guarantees for non-i.i.d. data.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we investigated the label-skewed non-i.i.d. data quagmire in federated learning and proposed a local importance sampling based framework, ISFL. We derived the theoretical guarantees of ISFL, as well as the solutions of the optimal IS weights using a water-filling approach. In particular, we improved the theoretical compatibility with the neural network models by relaxing the convexity assumptions. The ISFL algorithm was also developed and evaluated on the CIFAR-10 dataset. The experimental results demonstrated the improvement of ISFL for the non-i.i.d. data from several aspects. ISFL promotes the accuracy of basic FL and nearly reaches the performance of the centralized model using the integrated non-i.i.d. data. ISFL also shows its potentials on sampling efficiency and data robustness. This is significant for FL, especially for the mobile light-weight scenarios.

For future work, more tests on the theorems and the performance of ISFL can be investigated. For instance, the finer-grained analysis of the parameter deviation and the gradient Lipschitz approximation can be studied. The other types of non-i.i.d. settings such as feature based non-i.i.d. cases shall also be considered. The potential strengths for local personalization can be further developed by setting the {pi}subscript𝑝𝑖\{p_{i}\} different for each client. In addition, since ISFL is a local sampling federated scheme, it can be easily migrated into other emerging FL frameworks as a key operation block.

Appendix A Proof of The Convergence Theorem

To derive the convergence result in Theorem 1, we firstly show some preliminaries and then complete the proofs.

A-A Proof Preparations

Ahead of the proofs, we define some extra shorthand notations for the simplicity of writing as follows.

tcsubscript𝑡𝑐t_{c}: The latest aggregation epoch, i.e., tc=⌊tEl⌋⋅Elsubscript𝑡𝑐⋅𝑡subscript𝐸𝑙subscript𝐸𝑙t_{c}=\lfloor\frac{t}{E_{l}}\rfloor\cdot E_{l}.

𝜽¯t=∑k=1Kπk​𝜽tksubscript¯𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜋𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑘𝑡\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t}=\sum\limits_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{k}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{k}_{t}: The aggregated model at t𝑡t-epoch. A-B Proof of Theorem 1

+η2​L¯𝒯2​∑k=1Kπk​σk2​(t)−η2​‖∇ℓ​(𝜽¯t)‖2+η​C​G2​(t)superscript𝜂2subscript¯𝐿𝒯2superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜋𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2𝑡𝜂2superscriptnorm∇ℓsubscript¯𝜽𝑡2𝜂𝐶superscript𝐺2𝑡\displaystyle+\frac{\eta^{2}\bar{L}_{\mathcal{T}}}{2}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\pi_{k}\sigma_{k}^{2}(t)-\frac{\eta}{2}\big{\|}\nabla\ell(\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t})\big{\|}^{2}+\eta CG^{2}(t)

(26)

Since the practical learning rates of neural networks are commonly recommended to be set as a small value such as 1e-3 for better training stability. For proper small learning rate satisfying η​L¯𝒯≤1𝜂subscript¯𝐿𝒯1\eta\bar{L}_{\mathcal{T}}\leq 1, the first term in (26) can be omitted. ≤−η2​T​∑t=T0T1‖∇ℓ​(𝜽¯t)‖2+η2​ψ​(𝒯)absent𝜂2𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡subscript𝑇0subscript𝑇1superscriptnorm∇ℓsubscript¯𝜽𝑡2𝜂2𝜓𝒯\displaystyle\leq-\frac{\eta}{2T}\sum_{t=T_{0}}^{T_{1}}\big{\|}\nabla\ell(\bar{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{t})\big{\|}^{2}+\frac{\eta}{2}\psi(\mathcal{T})

(27)

Finally, taking the term of gradient norm to the left-hand side, (27) leads to (1). ∎

Appendix B Proofs of The Optimal IS Strategies

B-A Proof of Theorem 2

We firstly derive the Theorem 2, which gives the theoretical solution of the optimal IS probabilities.

Proof of Theorem 2.

The theorem is the solution to the sub-problem 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}}. For simplicity, we denote the two terms of ρ𝒯​(𝒒k)subscript𝜌𝒯superscript𝒒𝑘\rho_{\mathcal{T}}(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) respectively by

A​(𝒒k)𝐴superscript𝒒𝑘\displaystyle A(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) =1+∑i=1C(pi−qik)2,absent1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑖2\displaystyle=1+\sum_{i=1}^{C}(p_{i}-q^{k}_{i})^{2}, (28a)
B​(𝒒k)𝐵superscript𝒒𝑘\displaystyle B(\boldsymbol{q}^{k}) =∑i=1Cqik​Lk,i2​(𝒯).absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑖𝒯\displaystyle=\sum_{i=1}^{C}q^{k}_{i}L^{2}_{k,i}(\mathcal{T}). (28b)

It is easy to check that the objective function is convex on 𝒒ksuperscript𝒒𝑘\boldsymbol{q}^{k}. Therefore, to derive the solution of 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}}, we formulate the Lagrangian function:

ℒ=A​(𝒒k)⋅B​(𝒒k)−λ​(∑i=1Cqi−1)−∑i=1Cμi​(qik−ϖ​pik),ℒ⋅𝐴superscript𝒒𝑘𝐵superscript𝒒𝑘𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscript𝑞𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscript𝜇𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑘italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑘\mathcal{L}=A(\boldsymbol{q}^{k})\cdot B(\boldsymbol{q}^{k})-\lambda\Big{(}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}q_{i}-1\Big{)}-\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}\mu_{i}\big{(}q_{i}^{k}-\varpi p_{i}^{k}\big{)}, (29)

where the scalar λ𝜆\lambda is the Lagrangian multiplier for the equality constraint and the vector multiplier 𝝁=[μ1,⋯,μC]𝝁subscript𝜇1⋯subscript𝜇𝐶\boldsymbol{\mu}=[\mu_{1},\cdots,\mu_{C}] is for the inequality constraint. Hence, the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions of 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} can be written as

∂ℒ∂qjk=2​(qjk−pj)​B+Lk,j2​(𝒯)​A−λ−μj=0ℒsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗𝐵subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑗𝒯𝐴𝜆subscript𝜇𝑗0\displaystyle\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial q_{j}^{k}}=2(q_{j}^{k}-p_{j})B+L^{2}_{k,j}(\mathcal{T})A-\lambda-\mu_{j}=0 (30a)
∑i=1Cqik=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑖𝑘1\displaystyle\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}q_{i}^{k}=1 (30b)
μj≥0subscript𝜇𝑗0\displaystyle\mu_{j}\geq 0 (30c)
qjk≥ϖ​pjksuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘\displaystyle q_{j}^{k}\geq\varpi p_{j}^{k} (30d)
μj​(ϖ​pjk−qjk)=0subscript𝜇𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘0\displaystyle\mu_{j}(\varpi p_{j}^{k}-q_{j}^{k})=0 (30e)

where j=1,⋯,C𝑗1⋯𝐶j=1,\cdots,C. Note that for (30c)-(30e), μj=0subscript𝜇𝑗0\mu_{j}=0 holds if qjk>ϖ​pjksuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘q_{j}^{k}>\varpi p_{j}^{k}. Thus, we are able to adopt a water-filling method to solve the KKT conditions with inequality constraints. Specifically, we can firstly assume that μj=0subscript𝜇𝑗0\mu_{j}=0 for all j𝑗j and then adjust each qjk⁣∗subscriptsuperscript𝑞𝑘𝑗q^{k*}_{j} to satisfy (30d). qjk=pj+λ−Lk,j2​(𝒯)​A2​Bsuperscriptsubscript𝑞𝑗𝑘subscript𝑝𝑗𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑗𝒯𝐴2𝐵q_{j}^{k}=p_{j}+\frac{\lambda-L^{2}_{k,j}(\mathcal{T})A}{2B} (31)

A=C​λ∑i=1CLk,i2​(𝒯)𝐴𝐶𝜆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝐿2𝑘𝑖𝒯A=\frac{C\lambda}{\sum\limits_{i=1}^{C}L^{2}_{k,i}(\mathcal{T})} (32)

By substituting (32) and (33) into (31), we obtain

=pj+αjk​(𝒯)⋅Γk​(λ).absentsubscript𝑝𝑗⋅subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯subscriptΓ𝑘𝜆\displaystyle=p_{j}+\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})\cdot\Gamma_{k}(\lambda). (34)

Here, we obtain the solutions to 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} in Theorem 2. ∎

B-B Proof of Theorem 3

Theorem 3 directs the calculation of the coefficient ΓΓ\Gamma to obtain the optimal IS weights in practical algorithms. We sketch the proof as follows.

Proof of Theorem 3.

Practically, ϖitalic-ϖ\varpi is set as a small value to ensure that all categories contribute to the local training. Besides, as the category distribution of all data, each pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j} shall not be too small. Thus, it is natural to assume that pj≥ϖ​pjksubscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘p_{j}\geq\varpi p_{j}^{k} holds in most cases. Moreover, note that the factors {αjk​(𝒯)}subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯\{\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})\} satisfy the zero-sum property. The water-filling approach will then lead to pj+αjk​(𝒯)​Γ≥ϖ​pjksubscript𝑝𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯Γitalic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘p_{j}+\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})\Gamma\geq\varpi p_{j}^{k} for each j𝑗j. That is,

Γ≥pj−ϖ​pjk−αjk​(𝒯)i​fαjk​(𝒯)>0,formulae-sequenceΓsubscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯𝑖𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯0\displaystyle\Gamma\geq\frac{p_{j}-\varpi p_{j}^{k}}{-\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})}\ \ \ \ if\ \ \ \alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})>0, (35a)
Γ≤pj−ϖ​pjk−αjk​(𝒯)i​fαjk​(𝒯)<0.formulae-sequenceΓsubscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯𝑖𝑓subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯0\displaystyle\Gamma\leq\frac{p_{j}-\varpi p_{j}^{k}}{-\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})}\ \ \ \ if\ \ \ \alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})<0. (35b)

(35a) always holds because the right-hand side is smaller than 00 while Γ≥0Γ0\Gamma\geq 0. Therefore, the optimal Γ∗superscriptΓ\Gamma^{*} shall satisfy (35b). By setting ΓΓ\Gamma as the smallest non-negative pj−ϖ​pjk−αjk​(𝒯)subscript𝑝𝑗italic-ϖsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝛼𝑘𝑗𝒯\frac{p_{j}-\varpi p_{j}^{k}}{-\alpha^{k}_{j}(\mathcal{T})}, the numerical solutions to 𝒫𝒯ksubscriptsuperscript𝒫𝑘𝒯\mathcal{P}^{k}_{\mathcal{T}} can be obtained. ∎
